Term.definition: An event that disrupts normal program flow, usually due to an error.
The act of calling or executing a function or method in code.
Multiple versions of a function with the same name but different parameters.
Values passed to a function to customize its behavior.
A data structure that holds multiple elements, such as lists or sets.
Multiple methods with the same name but different parameter lists in a class.
A statement that defines a function, variable, or class, specifying its name and type.
A function that returns true or false for a given input.
A sequence of characters defining a search pattern, often used for string matching.
A named storage location in code that holds a value which can change during execution.
Annotation indicating a variable or parameter can hold a null value.
Annotation indicating a variable or parameter cannot hold a null value.
Allowing operators like + or == to have user-defined behavior for custom types.
A function used to define ordering between objects, returning negative, zero, or positive integer.
An interface for objects that can be ordered or compared to each other.
A function added to an existing class without modifying its source code.
A way to create an anonymous object with a specific type or interface implementation.
A class declared and instantiated in a single expression, often for one-time use.
A function added to an existing class without modifying its source code.
A value passed to a function or method when it is called.
A helper function that performs a common, reusable operation.
A function or property added to a class without modifying its source code.
A special modifier that allows overloading standard operators like +, -, or () in Kotlin.
Functions that add new functionality to existing classes without modifying their source code.
A collection of pre-written code and utilities provided by a programming language.
Functions that add new behavior to existing classes without modifying their source code.
A function that returns true or false for a given input.
A special value representing the absence of any object or value.
The process of converting a collection of collections into a single collection containing all elements.
A way to refer to functions or properties directly, using ::, instead of lambdas.
Anonymous functions that can be passed as arguments or assigned to variables.
A sequence of function calls, usually on collections, where each call returns an object for the next.
An operation that modifies the original data structure instead of creating a new one.
A data structure or object whose contents can be changed after creation.
A data structure that holds multiple elements, such as lists, sets, or maps.
Kotlin function that creates a read-only map from key-value pairs.
A Kotlin syntax for unpacking parts of an object into separate variables.
A set operation that returns elements common to all given sets.
A boolean variable indicating a true/false or on/off state in programming.
Anonymous functions that can be passed as arguments or used inline in Kotlin.
Data structures that hold multiple elements, such as lists, sets, or maps in Kotlin.
A function that sets the value of a property, often allowing custom logic during assignment.
A function that retrieves the value of a property in a class or object.
A function or expression used to set the initial value of a variable or property.
Objects that handle the implementation of a propertyâ€™s getter and setter for another class.
A delegate that initializes a property only upon its first access.
Objects that handle the getter and setter logic for a property on behalf of another class.
Functions that add new functionality to existing classes without modifying their source code.
Functions that add new functionality to existing classes without modifying their source code.
A lambda expression that can access members of a specified receiver object via 'this'.
A function that adds new functionality to an existing class without modifying it.
A mutable map implementation that stores key-value pairs using a hash table.
Kotlin functions that execute a block of code within the context of an object.
A value passed to a function or method when it is called.
The entry point function where program execution begins in Kotlin applications.
An implicit parameter in a lambda or function, representing the object on which members are accessed.
A function defined without a name, often used as a lambda or anonymous function.
A function that returns true or false for a given input, often used for filtering.
The definition of a function's name, parameters, and return type.
A keyword that changes the behavior or visibility of classes, functions, or properties.
A program that translates source code into executable code or bytecode.
Java keyword to check if an object is an instance of a specific class.
Java exception thrown to indicate a method has received an inappropriate argument.
A Kotlin expression for conditional branching, similar to switch in other languages.
A statement that gives instructions to the compiler, such as import or package in Kotlin.
A class representing numbers as fractions with a numerator and denominator.
Fixed sequences of characters in code, representing constant text values.
Kotlin feature allowing variables and expressions inside string literals using $ or ${} syntax.
Predefined functions provided by a programming language's standard library for common tasks.
An event that disrupts normal program flow, often due to errors or unexpected conditions.
A program that translates source code into executable code, checking for errors in the process.
Kotlin function that creates a new read-only map from given key-value pairs.
Kotlin function that creates a new read-only list containing specified elements.
Executing operations only when needed, rather than processing all data upfront.
Processing all data immediately, rather than deferring operations until needed.
Domain-Specific Language; a mini-language tailored for a specific aspect of a program.
A property ensuring that variables are used only with compatible data types at compile time.
